Quoth abeacock@...:
  [...]
> As my tearDown() 'null's out the source and listener objects so that 
> they get cleaned up, there really is no need for the final line 
> "source.removeSomeKindOfChangeListener(..."
> 
> My question is regarding whether it's best to try to keep the tests as 
> simple as possible or to show correct usage.  After all, the remove 
> method should definitely be used in production code.
> 
> What do you all think?

Although I don't know much about the situation, my first
inclination is to move the calls which add and remove the listener
out of the individual test methods and into setUp and tearDown. 
Best of both worlds -- simpler tests without giving up correct
usage.

If the individual test methods need to their own specialized
listeners for the tests to work, then perhaps they don't belong in
the same test fixture.
subject: Re: [junit] Test simplicity or correct usage
